name: 60 Seconds!
description: 60 Seconds! is a dark comedy atomic adventure of scavenge and survival. Collect supplies and rescue your family before the nuke hits. Stay alive in your fallout shelter. Make difficult decisions, ration food and hunt mutant cockroaches. And maybe survive. Or not.
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows XP SP3 (32/64 bit) or later Processor: Intel Core™ 2 Duo 2.0+ GHz or an equivalent AMD CPU Memory: 4 GB RAM Graphics: nVidia GeForce 8800 GT or AMD Radeon HD2900 XT (with 512MB VRAM) DirectX: Version 9.0c Storage: 3 GB available space Additional Notes: Keyboard and mouse required, Microsoft Xbox 360 controller optional

reviews.review_text: 60 Seconds! is a combination of an action game and a text-based survival game. You play as Ted, the air raid siren has just sounded and you have 60 seconds to grab supplies and family members and get down to your fallout shelter before the bombs hit. Once in your shelter you begin a fight for survival as you ration food, try to make contact with help and venture out into the radioactive wastes.   +Great art style, really feels like it's in the 1950's +The 60 seconds portion of the game is rather unique +Each run has a different story but it's always interesting +Early on in your run it's a real struggle to survive and the game provides you with a good challenge +As well as food and water you have a number of other resources to manage which can be used in certain situations +Some situations have rather amusing outcomes while others have outcomes which threaten the survival of the family +The appearance of the family members changes as the longer they stay in the bunker and appearances also change when they become ill or similar +Most situations can be approached in different ways, for example if there's a dark, unexplored room you can use a flashlight to see what's in there or use your gun to scare off possible hostiles +If, like me, you aren't so keen on the 60 seconds part you can start from the bunker and you'll be given a random selection of resources and family members making it feel like a rogue-like +The writing, until it gets repetitive, is great +Great humour +Great tutorial  -The controls for the 60 seconds in the house aren't great, they're very insensitive and sometimes the control for picking up an item doesn't work even when you're standing next to it which is very frustrating -After around Day 60 it just becomes a case of clicking through the text to get to the next day without doing anything -Sometimes the game presents you with situations you can't actually do due to you not having the right item which is also quite frustrating -The writing gets repetitive quite quickly, in my first run I got to Day 78 (before my save got corrupted) and I saw some situations four or five times  Verdict: Worth Purchasing (7.5/10)  An interesting idea combined with great text-based survival with a great art style, interesting stories, good humour and good writing.  El K.
60 seconds from love to hate, from admiration to disappointment, from adventure's foretaste to boredom...   It's about:

This is truly an amazing indie game! It might seem like a very simple concept but it's really much more than just 'simple'. I like how the game makes you think questions like 'If I answer yes here, will this or either that happen next?'. Not every ingame mode is the same and what makes the most changes are your own choices, awesome isn't it? :D  Some of the pros and cons in my opinion;  +The mix between art styles, first 3D and then cartoonish style +Large variety of choices, endings etc. +Runs on lower-end machines +Good soundtracks and sound effects +Some humor here and there  -Still has a lot potential in terms of content -Even more variety as some of the text lines and/or choices are seen pretty often, maybe even too often  Overall rating: 10/10. Why? Because the game itself is stable, working and very fun to play. Even though more content and some variety changes would be greatly appreciated. Plus I got the game off the anniversary sale, so -50% price, couldn't stop myself from buying this :D

DAY 1: Loots the whole house and then forgets the family takes them all in the last second and jumps down to my little shelter doenst give anyone food and then goes to sleep.  DAY 2: Giving food to noone and goes to sleep  DAY 3: Radio active spiders attacking! What do i do use the spray or scout handbook picks book.  Mary jane gets bitten becomes a purple mutant.  DAY 4: Mary jane is feeling bad decides to talk with her, she attacks Dollores (MOM) Dollores gets hurt goes to sleep.  DAY 5: Gives everyone except Mary jane water because she is a mutant and remember kids mutants only need food not water!  DAY: 6 Military contact! Getting a singlal from the military good thing i brought that damn radio they ask me to get rid of my weapons. I say to my family They may take our freedom but they will never take our weapons! USA! USA! USA!  DAY: 8 Military contact again they send on the radio that they will do a supply drop i decided that timmy should take a gasmask and go out and search for it. He comes back with a bunch of food and water  DAY:9 Did you notice i skipped DAY: 7 hah and now you go back and check. But on day 9 or 7 nothing cool happens.  DAY: 10 We decided to take a quick peak outside and there are 2 red glowing eyes in the darkness what do we do?1? Take our flashlight or rifle. I decided to take the flashlight and it showed up that it was a dog thag looked very hungry we brought the dog down to our shelter and gave it some soup. Pancake will stay for the rest of the day and possible the night.  DAY:11 Pancakes leaves the shelter we say goodbye to him and then we eat breakfast We decided that Ted should go out and scavange we're running low on supplies.   DAY: 12 We wake up by someone knocking on the door we decided to open and it was the military we are saved!     Thank you for reading please like if this helped you in any way!
Kill the children, save the food!

This game is a lot of fun! The developers do a good job updating and adding new content to keep the game fresh and fun. I love screwing around in the game and finding funny moments (I won't spoil them). It's also fun to create your own personal challenges to complete for fun. There are lots out there, search around and find your favourite!  Overall, 60 Seconds is a great game with a ton of replay value! $10 is a perfect price for it which means if it's ever on sale, there's no excuse not to buy it!

I want to love this game, I REALLY do, but this is ridiculous.  Some might say that the difficulty I experience from this game may be bad RNG. I would agree with this statement if not for the fact that it feels as if the game is intentionally stacking things against you. Example: 'Game: Oh, I see you have the gas mask, radio, and flashlight, here have an earthquake. Enjoy choosing which one you want to keep! And by the way, I'm going to give you an event tomorrow that will break whichever one you choose. Bye!' All I can do is sit there and go 'REALLY!?!?!' as I flip of the screen repeatedly.  Don't get me wrong, it is a nice game and I do recomend it, ONLY IF you are willing to put up with frustration and tons of attempts just trying to get a good start.

The concept is great, but the gameplay, gets boring after a while. So if youre looking for a good, quick game for a gameplay video, you should get this game, but at the same time, dont, because its outdated as hell now that markiplier played it. 3/5 [★★★☆☆]

A perfect mix of choose your own adventure and the apocalypse. This game is great and the 60 Seconds Mechanic is something you will not find anywhere else.  Makes me realize I should never have thrown out my old boy scout manual.
not normally the type of game i go for but its neat and tidy and lots of fun worth the money i paid

Survive as a family or as a couple, but surviving alone isn't an option. Insanity is real and if Ted goes insane, game over, he'll run away. A challenging survival game based in the nuclear fallout that could've happened during WWII. You get only 1 minute to gather everything you can, so be sure to note where things are prior to that one minute. If you don't gather enough or save too many people, you will run out of supplies very quickly in the shelter. Keep sicknesses in check or it will kill your people, and many other things provide challenges based on RNG. The overall feel to the game is cartoonish with tongue and cheek comedy, and it has some interesting easter eggs in it. I'd give it a 7/10 , it's fun and worth a playthrough at least once! Different outcome everytime almost gurranteed.
well i'm a simple man i can choose to kill my wife and kids  that is enought to convince me to buy it

This game is very good!  It gives the player a challenge and gives a choice and multiple endings and is really fun! And the game's art style is very nice! So i say that the ten dollars is so worth it!  TED AND MR. SOCK! UNITE!
I've never lived to see another Dancing Mutated Cockroach    -Great game

Warning: there be spoilers ahead!!! I think this is a beautiful game, where it shows real life problems, and sprinkles comedy in there! there are two 'major' 'bugs', but they are both avoidable. The first- (at least for me) the game crashes after the intro, skip the intro. The turning is laggy during the beginning stage (especially if you have a lot of crap on the computer, which i do), I just skip the first part entirely, and i heard hooking up a controller works as well. I love the humor in the game, the only complaint is that some situations (bandits threatening to break down my door and the radio saying I need to cut down trees - my axe broke when healing Mary Jane earlier, so i dont know what happens if you cut down the trees, but it would be close to impossible to think up new situations in a game where you can survive for over 113 days (my record is 113, timmy ran away because he was sick, the wife was taken while scavenging, mary jane burst through the door because i didnt talk to her, and the shelter was overrun by a preacher while ted was scavenging) I like how most actions have consequences. i think it was worth all 10$, but if you dont like repeditivity, slightly crude humor, or mutant cockroaches, i recomend a different game. if you are fine with everything i listed, play it!

I have so many questions!! (bottom of review for legit comments on the game)  1.) For starters why would someone build a Fallout Shelter in their house; then decide not to fill it at all.  2.) Why doesn't Ted's family get their lazy asses up and grab stuff with me when the alarm goes off? 3.) How does a cockroach mutate after only 8 days of radiation, (I thought that Cockroachs were suppost to live through Nukes.) 4.) How come no one decides to ever load the gun if we have ammo and a Rifle? 5.) Why does rodant killer heal wounds in this game? 6.) Why do random cavemen drawings show up on the sides of my shelter? 7.) So Ted decided to put all that furnature down there, (chairs, Shelves, etc.), but no supplies at all? 8.) How does a can of soup last EXACTLY 737 years according to this game? 9.) Why do you need a suit case to carry more than one item on your journey? 10.) Finally, and most importantly, why do the dead bodies of my family keep their hair?!?!  Someone please explain!! But in all honesty, this is a good game with some flaws, but overall a very decent game!  7/10 (get it on sale)
Very nice. Warning: requires the ability to read and familiarity with words such as idyllic and analphabetic. Apparently that's offputting for some.
survived over 80 nights. And got rescued.        I am such a cool kid

A text-based adventured game with a unique twist set in an alternate reality during the ColdWar where the Soviet Union actually nukes us. This is a game hwere you have exactly 60 seconds after the sirens go off to gather everthing you can possibly bear and get into your shelter before you succumb to nukes. After wards you live out your life, waiting for the military to rescue you....or what fate might bring to you otherwise.  This game is a load of fun to play. The physics are hilarious, the dialouge hits home, but never goes overboard, and the asthetics are while not with great fidelity, perfect for the scenery, especially since it is depicting a depressing period in history.  If you are into these sort of text-based adventure games, then give this one a go! It certainly hits the mark in my books, and there have been many comic and tragic memories from this game that I will forever treasure.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The game is poorly titled. First things first, this game comes in two parts:  Part1: getting the stuff you need in your home before the nukes drop.   You only have 60 secondes (title of the game) , and you have the choice between taking all of your family or not or taking loads of water and no weapons depends on what you grab first.   This concept of the game is poorly developped I mean on this first part I see a gameplay of a free game you get from a flash game on internet. The idea was not well tought out.  Part2 : This is where things get fun, the game gets real interesting on the survival part. Taking decision that might end the lives of your survivors or it might also give you exactly what you need. Even if it demands some luck it demands a lot of risk taking which is exactly what at least I was looking for.   Even if that game is very fun it does not have enough content and I wish the game creators would have tough about it a little more and added game changing details. This is a good game but not worth it's orgin price it is worth half.  Cons:  -Origin Price too High -FIrst part of the game is kinda of rubbish (poor graphics, weird camera angle) -Seconde part of the game does not have enough content   Pros: -Lots of different events  -Great game idea

Somehow the game does not recognise my clicks when I use this, so lately I have been unable to play. This naturally does not detract from the quality of the game, just from my personal experience with it.

60 Seconds! is a fun Comedy adventure game, you got 60 seconds to scavenge soup and water for food, games and radio for sanity, guns and tools for usefullness, get as much as you can and get to your shelter before time runs out, Then its up to you to make it in your shelter till you are saved.          YouTube™ Video:  60 Seconds - Gameplay - The Apocalypse

I wanted to play fallout so a bought this game its not fallout ;[

Picked this game up as it looked pretty interesting. I liked the concept of the bunker survival game. However, the scavenge sequence just felt too choppy for me, may have been the poor performing pc I am currently using, but loved the survival only option. I enjoyed the choices that had to be made throughout the survival experience, the first time or so, but I quickly found myself having the same options everytime. The writing was one aspect I really did enjoy. The journal to flip through everyday made each day of surviving pretty humurous, granted that there was a unique experience the day before. The generally short playthoughs made the game somewhat fun, but as I mentioned I ran into the same scenarios quite a few times.  Overall, I would say this is a great game if you need to kill a short period of time, possibly more ideal as a mobile game (speaking of course of the survival mode). If the developers made this into a mobile game, I'd probably pick it up and enjoy it occassionally in situations like waiting at the doctor's office, airport terminal, etc. Lastly, the $10 price is a little steep for the experience I had, but since this is Steam, I would say snag it if you're interested and it's on sale for about $5.
keeps crashing when tring to start it
'My wife, and children are dead, but at least I have you Soupy!' -Every Ted Ever! #Tedlife
Too much lag ;-; And always crashes when I open it.. I still recommend because it is fun, only if I could play it.

I've only played a little so far, but I love it. This is a game that can really stress you out. I almost broke my computer because of this game. But I love it, it really requires you to think on your feet at the beginning.  The gameplay in the shelter slows the game down, but it is still stressful when Ted gets bit by an aligator because he didn't have an gun, or when Timmy goes insane because you didn't have a checkerboard, or when you can't win becuse you can't find a flashlight fo the life of you. I love it nevertheless and give it a 9/10 because there's a glitch where all sound but the radio cuts off when I click on the radio.

Great Game! Fun game but my problem is it gets boring after a long time. I was deciding between recommended and not, and I sided with recommended. After you beat the game, there is not much else to do. I beat the game on the 2nd try (I looked up how to beat it), and got bored after that, but a fun game when you play it. I like how you make decisions and it has a whole path just for one choice, but sometimes the same choices pop up and give me the same answer. Overall, I recommend this game like 55(Good)/45(Bad).

Its a very fun and intense game, of course it might be a bit repetetive if you play it long enough, but overall I think i'ts good. Basically there's this nuclear explosion that happens, and you have 60 seconds to gather your family and as much supplies as you can, and then try to survive as long as you can in your bunker until the military rescues you.  Afcourse you also have to send people out to scavenge ocassionaly. Especially when you're low on supplies, there will be different types of events such as bandits trying to raid you, dealing with cockroaches, and animals or creatures trying to steal your food. For that you will need different items to deal with those problems.  And that's about it. I rate the game 6.5/10
Which family memebers do you want to take with you during 60 seconds before a nuke goes? How much food? water? entertainment? or just go crazy and die already

Yes, this game is a lot of fun. Good for killing time and can be played as a serious campaign game if need be. The game is a lot of fun because the story always changes. The events are not always the same, and you have to make careful choices. I would recommend this game to anyone who likes to survival games, decision making games, and humorous games. Overall a 8 out of 10.

Brilliant! I first saw Jackspeticeye play 60 seconds on his channel and thought it looked a lot easier. Now that I have played it, I have to say I'm going to be sticking to easy for a little while! 60 seconds is NOWHERE near the amount of time you would think, especially with the difficulty of grabbing items and family for your shelter.

Fun game, but frustrating mechanics.  It is a really fun game to play, but the searching for food section is so impossible because of the mechanics. The turns are choppy, picking things up takes several click attempts, and dropping things down the shaft takes a couple clicks too. You can't really get enough supplies to last you.  The survival part of the game is super fun though.  I would recommend this game, but only if you get it on sale.

Although my PC isnt good enough to run anything except Survival mode, I still had a good time playing this game. However, winning isnt as easy as it first seems. In fact, all the hours I've played on 60 Seconds was a complete waste of time. Not because the game wasn't fun, but because i badly failed the whole way through. I can only pray that i might, one day, complete this game. Then, I'll turn up the difficulty. Oh god. :/

The idea behind it is great and interesting, but the execution is not impressive enough to make 60 seconds! a high quality game. I found that bandits appear way too often after a month which means you'll be screwed soon after they start invading. Also medkits are too rare when it comes to getting sick. The idea of this game is what generally hooked me in for a moment. Overall the game is good enough for at least few hours.

This game is ok. It's hard to decide whether I should recommend or not. The idea is cool. The implementation is so-so. Love the cartoony graphics and the imagery. I also like the day-to-day events and comedy bits. But this game gets old pretty quick. I guess I will recommend it. It was entertaining for a time, but I guess that will be the caveat to my recommendation. Don't buy this expecting to get a lot of playtime/replayability out of it.

60 seconds is a fun game to play. It can get quite addictive. I like the sort of random effect each day has. It doesn't take too long to master the game though, and if you watch a few gameplays of it and play the game yourself, you'll know everything that you need to know. The narrative and story is simple, but good. And the randomness ensures that it doesn't always end the same way.   However, the price does seem like a bit much. It's just 7 dollars, which really isn't a lot, but there have been more detailed games with better storylines and more gameplay for a smaller price.   Overall, I'd recommend for a few hours of fun. It can get quite hard though, but I liked it.

Pretty fun game, it's easy to learn but a little tricky to actually win. Despite being a bit on the darker side, I loved the journal entries and events. I would definitely recommend this if you're looking for a comic like apocalypse game.
it is fun if you like to read alot like me and if you like to think and solve problems like and give mercy or no mercy at all then this game is for you

It takes a while for you to realize it, but this game is really about reading and getting lucky.  Events generate randomly and most outcomes are random. You can't really make an informed and intelligent decision in most cases. Scavenging rewards are extremely random as well...  Gameplay is just about clicking on choices. No recorded dialog, no animations, no level design. The whole thing becomes quite repetitive, as does the soundtrack.  So basically, if you're a very lucky person that loves to read the same sentences over and over, then I do recommend the game for you :-).

While the initial 60 seconds of a game is a frantic dash to throw supplies and your family into the bunker, the remaining part of the game is a text adventure. That's right, 95% of this game is you reading text and deciding what to do next. See that notebook featured in the previews of the game? That's what you look at 95% of the time. That's the game.

It looks good at first on Youtube. But it is so gliched out when your getting things. You get stuck on things, and some things even block your path. It is not easy to move unless you use a controller. Don't spend your money on this unless you have a controller.

I kinda expected that when you choose someone to go out and explore you'd take control of them or something... The title is right though, you have 60 seconds of gameplay and then rest is a text based adventure, it has potential to become a good game and the concept is good but it's so basic and barebones that I couldn't really enjoy it. I honestly think the most enjoyable part was the first 60 seconds...  For now I could only recommend the game to those who enjoy text based adventures, but unfortunately that's about as far as this game goes, worst of all it's quite repetitive early on and it doesn't really give you a lot of choices. I personally don't find games like this enjoyable, if it had a little bit more in the way of 'actual' exploration then I think it would've been a lot better.

60 Seconds is an interesting adventure in decision making. Some days you get the carrot and more often than not, you get the radioactive Commie Beating Stick. I love the aesthetics, I love the 1950's scare of nuclear war, the mad dash you need to make to get your family into the shelter, to slowly watch as the bunker drives everyone into the dirt. I love it all as a game, but my biggest draw, and unfortunately this was the thing that made me refund it, was the fact there is so little to do.   The game looks good, it sounds good and it plays well but it becomes boring just clicking the same menus after each day. I appreciate the craft made to show things both being damaged or used such as a torn gas mask, ripped up map or having Timmy wear a colander and holding a squirrel (if I remember correctly). I just don't recommend buying this for 10 dollars.   Maybe if a few minigames or a few other features were thrown in it'd be a lot more fun. But the mad dash at the beginning is the biggest core component of its gameplay. Sure you can play the tutorial, practice getting supplies & eventually running the full game and seeing where you stand. My longest streak was 40 days and when I played for the first hour, it was a lot of fun but I noticed it was very repetitive. Maybe that's part of the point, and if so, sorry I missed it. Sending people out is about the second funnest part of the game aside from the overall decision making process. I just wish there was more control over it. More to do. I'd like to pick the place I could go maybe, maybe pick the actions I make or what supplies. The game is very text intensive, and I apprciate that, so I don't see why we couldn't have some more prompts out in the field or handling situations.  I felt bad refunding this game, because I really like the idea but $10.00 for something like this, compared to say a game like LISA, it kind of really draws points against itself for $10.00. If this game had a little more, just some more decisions, maybe a bigger house, maybe a smaller house, maybe just a few more options to really make it your own experience, with maybe a bit more gameplay elements, and I'd have kept it wholeheartedly. I'd like to maybe rename the Wife and Kids and Ted as it were. It'd make me feel more involved.  I mean I could feel their plight, being stuck somewhere for a long period is no fun. So if I missed the point, again I'm sorry but I feel like this would make a good game to give a kid in his younger ages like maybe 11 to 13 and say 'here have some fun with this' and it'd satisfy their desire to make decisions, but for me, it didn't hold my attention long enough combined with the price point.   I'll be honest, I'll pick it up again when it goes on sale probably because I see hope for it. I just wish I didn't have to feel like I wasn't getting my moneys worth.  The design? Good. The sound? Satisfying. Gameplay? Lacking, my biggest point against it. I hope this game grows and the people who made it continue to add to it, but as it stands I don't recommend it for the combined price point and lack of overall variety

A playful jab at Cold War Americana, a choose your own adventure serial that could use more effort overall, and a game, in that order.  The art style effectively parodies the Reagan era suburban family. Most of the graphics are two dimentional sketches in which beauty will be in the eye of the beholder, but I largely found unimpressive and lacking in variety. The three dimentional gameplay segment is function, but equally forgettable art wise. Music also fails to linger after the game is switched off.  The game is effectively two games in one. The first being a time management puzzle evocative of the game's title. The second being a decision driven visual novel. The two elements don't inherently feel connected, save that your performance in the former slightly enhances your experience of the latter. The game itself seems to realize this as either segment can be played independent of the other through some of the default options. For two games, two reviews are in order.  The time management puzzle is a glorified random number generator. Tasked with procuring the best and most necessary supplies for your fallout shelter in 60 seconds, the fact that all supplies are randomly scattered throughout the house on each playthrough, while the house's layout is fixed, means that you'll naturally develop an optimal path for maximum stuff accumulation, hoping that the correct stuff is in the correct place. In short, the segment plays itself for the most part, aside from the infusion of varience in the form of player mistakes. Controls are slippery and require spamming clicks to force the avatar to execute the desired action, no doubt to raise tension but frustrating nevertheless.  The visual novel is full of delightful anachronisms that may induce a hee hawing from time to time, but they do repeat themselves frequently. You'll soon find yourself skipping through the family status updates and consequences of previous decisions to get to the meat and potatoes of your upcoming encounter. Most of the decisions in the game are focused on rewarding you for having the correct tool when prompted (or inversely punishing you for not having or using said tool). Some choices rely on your memory of previous encounters or informtion, which deliver a more satisfying sense of accomplishment when overcome and a sense of fair play on the game's part when you fall prey to them. For the most part though, luck is a large factor, making the exercise less about achieving victory and more about enjoying the story of your family victimized by the ravages of a pulp fiction nuclear holocaust.  Your $10.00s will buy you a few hours of entertainment from this title before it starts collecting virtual dust on your virtual shelf, awaiting the next major content update that may never come. You can do worse for the money, but you also could do better, and with the release of games like Stardew Valley, I find myself expecting more from my indie titles nowadays. If the idea of a pulpy, witty game about nuclear war and American values interests you, the Fallout series has been scratching that itch since the 1990s (Those games from the 1990s are likely obtainable at a comparable price tag to this title and absolutely dominate in comparison regarding content). Consequence driven visual novel lovers can get a more rewarding experience from the Telltale games or a dedicated visual novel game.

If i would describe this game in one word, it would be repetitive. The same 30 second loop of mediocore music, the same scenarios over and over again. Just, repetition. This game would be fine if it was some 2 dollar purchase of even a flash game. But for a 10 dollar purchase i think it is totally not worth it. I do not like. 2/10

This game is good, but its not worth $9.99. Not much to do for a game that is 10 dollars. I would me happy if they lower the price to $4.99.

It's times like this I feel the simple 'Yes, No' style of reviews aren't adaquete to really convey a person's feelings about a game. So while I can't recommend this game, neither do I feel the game isn't without merit.  The key thing to understand about 60 Seconds is that it is a game driven by a random number generator. All events, big or small, are a dice roll in regards to good fortune or bad fortune. Sometimes, you'll survive for months...other times you'll be lucky to last a week.   The biggest problem with the game is that, regardless of what you do or what supplies you take with you, there's very little you can do to affect the overall outcome of the game. Yes, Bug Spray can be used to make a replacement Medkit, and the Boy Scout Handbook is overall the best item you can take with you, but their value hinges on you getting the events to use those items...preferably before you get one of the fundamentally unfair disaster events, which forces you to choose between three supplies and you can only save one - nevermind how many people are in your shelter at the time.  60 Seconds is a game that has its charm. The art style is excellent, the humor witty, the writing is engaging (Until it grows stale from repeat views). Even the RNG aspect of the game can be engaging, if one is drawn to chance-based gameplay.  It's just that same RNG can quickly take the charm out of the game. Beyond the Boy Scout Handbook *always* being the best solution to any problem, there's actually very little you can do to influence the course of the game. Indeed, you can have all the pieces needed for rescue available, only to have it snatched from your hands by one of the aforementioned disaster events.   TL;DR Version: The game is flawed, but not without its charm. Wait for a sale, and give it a go. Just don't expect to win.

The game has an interesting premise. It was fun for my first and second play through but quickly got boring. It left me wanting more, not really to play more but gameplay wise. The game is $10, but I think a more fitting price would be ~$5.99. Only get it on sale if you're that interested.

Truth be told, I enjoyed the most of it.  But, if only we had something to do with tired, fatigue or crazy state... There are no options whatsoever to 'control' it. Just rationing the food, and that's it. Yes, you can feed the soup and make them drink, and also you can heal them, but you can't do anything about tiredness and fatigue. No concepts of getting a good sleep if got tired, neither regaining saneness through any controllable method was a big pain to me. I just had to wish the negative state to be fixed by luck when ending a day.

Good idea. Execution couldn't have been poorer.  The idea of this game, survival / comedy / tragedy during a nuclear holocaust is great. The game fails in every way to make this wonderful idea come to life.  Basically, it just wasn't built right. There are huge FPS lag issues which shouldn't be there considering what the game mechanics are. On the average gaming system, this game suffers. I can't speak to a $2000 gaming setup, but I imagine that's what you'd need for something that isn't highly technical.  This was a huge disappointment and I hope someone will take the idea and do it right.  I have to disagree with any comparison to Fallout. There is no similarity in my opinion.
It's called 60 seconds because it gets old after 60 seconds. RIP my poor wallet.

My Grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him. 'if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate. you have to stop immediately.' Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exacly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me - 'Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your Grandfather put us through'. I agreed. At 27, i have never touched a cigarette. I must say. I feel a very slight sense of regret for never having done it, because this game gave me cancer anyway.

There's simply not enough content here. After you've played the game for a couple of hours the humorous art style starts to wear off its charm and leaves you with an emptiness in your pocket.

Sadly, it crashes on my Macbook.  Update: Crashing is solved by tweaking settings, switching video quality down a bit and turning fullscreen off. Game is fun at first, though quiclky became repetetive and boring.
I would recommend this game if it we're five dollar. But right now I would say just pick up Fallout 3.

The games trailer tells what the game is about just not how it works out. Decision making gets repetitive as you come across the same issues at one point or a another. The concept of nuclear fallout decision making survival seems really great, and dont get me wrong it is a great game concept, but the nuclear wasteland experience doesnt fair well in this bare bones survival game. You cant control anyone after the first part where you collect items which takes away from the scavenge for survival aspect. After all you arent scavenging you are sending a family member out to collect some random items and get some disease most likely. Its a fun game and a great concept but has some major flaws and gets repetitive after the first few times you play it. I rate the game a 5/10.

Fun premise, but the frustrating controls, bugs, severe lag, and otherwise poor UI ruins the 60 second scavenge run that the game is supposed to be built around. The bulk of the game is spent on a mostly static image of the bunker where you ration supplies and make choices for random events that occur each day. This is entirely text based. If you loathe random number generators, then pack your bag full of soup cans and run for the hills. The game is briming with humor, however, the jokes will become repetitive as you will likely encounter the same events on each playthrough. If you can look past the clunky initial 3D portion of the game, you might find the choose-your-own-adventure style game amusing the first few playthroughs, but the replay value will likely diminish steeply. Worth buying if the developers optimize the game and the price drops to around $5.

The idea of this game is so very clever and so much of the artwork is spot-on with the theme but moving your character through the scavenge is onerous. It is shaky and more difficult than necessary getting around the house to collect items. Allowing shakiness for panic due to the nuclear apocolypse is a great idea but this inhibits game play and makes it no fun due to the feeling of not being able to control the character's movement.
